thread.title: Lower gas prices means no Social Security increase next year
thread.title_full: Lower gas prices means no Social Security increase next year - San Francisco Chronicle

author: Stephen Ohlemacher, Associated Press
title: Lower gas prices means no Social Security increase next year
text: Photo: Brett Carlsen, AP In this Friday, Oct. 9, 2015, photo, Glen Mead operates a line drill machine at a rock quarry, in Montrose, Pa. Mead spent his life working as a dairy farmer and at age 60, began working with Rock Ridge Stone in Montrose, to make ends meet. For just the third time in 40 years, millions of Social Security recipients, disabled veterans and federal retirees can expect no increase in benefits next year, unwelcome news for more than one-fifth of the nation's population. In this Friday, Oct. 9, 2015, photo, Glen Mead operates a line... WASHINGTON (AP) — For just the third time in 40 years, millions of Social Security recipients, disabled veterans and federal retirees can expect no increase in benefits next year, unwelcome news for more than one-fifth of the nation's population. In this Friday, Oct. 9, 2015, photo, Glen Mead operates a line drill machine at a rock quarry, in Montrose, Pa. Mead spent his life working as a dairy farmer and at age 60, began working with Rock Ridge Stone in Montrose, to make ends meet. For just the third time in 40 years, millions of Social Security recipients, disabled veterans and federal retirees can expect no increase in benefits next year, unwelcome news for more than one-fifth of the nation's population. In this Friday, Oct. 9, 2015, photo, Glen Mead operates a line... WASHINGTON (AP) — For just the third time in 40 years, millions of Social Security recipients, disabled veterans and federal retirees can expect no increase in benefits next year, unwelcome news for more than one-fifth of the nation's population.
